abstract.p: Federal Judge David N Hurd strikes down New York State law intended to limit Midwestern power plants' ability to produce pollution that causes acid rain; rules law interferes with federal program that allows industries to buy and sell pollution credits (S)

block.p: A federal judge has struck down a two-year-old New York State law that was intended to limit Midwestern power plants' ability to produce pollution that causes acid rain. Judge David N. Hurd ruled that the state law improperly interfered with a federal program that allows industries to buy and sell so-called pollution credits. The federal law, he wrote, ''does not permit one state to control emissions in another state.'' Under the state law, New York authorities could fine sellers of credits that New York said harmed the environment. Power companies sued, saying the law diminished the credits' value. The ruling leaves the credits program in place.
